title: Who will win the Democratic Party primary for the New York City mayoral election?
preds: New poll reveals Adams gains... NY Post link https://nypost.com/2021/06/21/eric-adams-holds-strong-lead-in-nyc-mayoral-race-poll/
Either Adams on first ballot, Yang or Garcia on second seems to be the most likely.

Eric Adams is winning according to a bunch of polls. I think if it's on first ballot seems likely to win. But it does seem like there will be 2nd ballots between Garcia + Yang. Yang has a few constituencies very interested in him that may not care about the media story + be less likely to respond to polls.

Recent polls suggest the race is pretty close between Adams, Garcia, Yang, and Wiley. Adams has a slight lead in some polls, Garcia in others, with Yang and Wiley consistently finishing 3rd and 4th. The race is consistently described as close in the news, so I'm very surprised that the crowd leans so strongly towards Eric Adams. He appears to be the favorite, but not by a huge margin.  Polls: 
https://www.city-journal.org/the-state-of-new-yorks-mayoral-race
https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2021/06/14/adams-garcia-top-latest-poll-in-new-york-mayors-race-1386402

Yang and Garcia were campaigning together this weekend but denied cross endorsing each other to gain ranking advantage. Local press reported this made Eric Adams furious. 
I'm out canvassing and talking to voters (on behalf of a NY City Council rep, not mayoral candidate) and most people say they don't know who this people are or what they stand for, masses going on name recognition and if that's decisive at all this year Adams and Yang would have the edge in terms of outreach via ads and mailers.

Eric Adams has mounted the most far reaching campaign and leads the polls. The endorsements and alliances surrounding him are not exactly what people in the city would describe as the politicians with the most integrity or overall record of accomplishment around, but they certainly know how to get in power.
Early voting has not been great, there's a lot of confusion and mistrust about vote ranking (will my favorite get hurt in the process if I rank others, how does it work, why does it matter, I dont know any of these people let me just mark first 5 names). People seem to be more uninformed than ever and are pretty much responding to the candidate with greater visibility (who can afford to bombard voters most with mailers and ads, texts and calls). 
But I still think there's a lot of unpredictability when it comes to the race given turn out and ranking.  The issues with Adams, the front runner, (he does live in NJ, has real estate holdings undisclosed to IRS, failing to pay taxes on them), and things like his recent comments to address education issues 
by suggesting we should keep remote learning, have 1 good teacher for 300 students via zoom, are true deal breakers for informed voters who are the most likely to show up to the polls. 
Yang's popularity started winding down, his optimistic attitude has gone far in many communities but his performance at the last debate where his approach was to come across as tough on crime (likely a main, decisive issue in the city now) was very polarizing given what many thought were insensitive, callous comments on people dealing with mental health issues. There is indeed an epidemic of houseless people with severe mental health issues seemingly in every corner of Manhattan. Many if not most of the subway attacks are related to that crisis. This resonates deeply with people, it's the one issue that affects people most directly and hits closer to home right now because it is so visible and present and it's also a symbolism of what the city has gone through and has yet failed to resolve.  We'll have to see what voters respond to best, if the compassionate, human rights focused approach to the mental health and houseless crisis or quick solution, make us feel safe approach by Yang.  People seem to be responding to politicians that are listening and leading with compassion in such a wounded place like NY. Taking a stroll in Midtown can be scary and depressing right now but in a place where so many have suffered a proposal to just get these people off your sight may mostly resonate with a small percentage who like Yang left the city during the height of the pandemic. 
Yang's plan to offer $2K per year to 500,000 people at a cost of $1 billion --his response to alleviate extreme poverty as he says --is one of his signature proposals but it's failing to catch up. He's being severely criticized for a proposal that gives people $5 a day while likely eliminating other programs that reach further than cash incentives.
Garcia is trusted as an efficient, trustworthy problem solver and has received very coveted endorsements. She is well balanced and her proposals are sound but doesn't seem like she has had a thorough outer boroughs outreach. 
Wiley is smart and experienced and has fought her way to the top candidates with great skills. She has also attracted a good number of small donations. Notable, seems likely that no one will get 50% of the vote or greater and decision will be decided by ranking. 
Newyorkers are tired, have little patience, having to wait over a month for election results might backfire in terms of participation. The city and state keeps pushing the story that we are back, we are open but it truly feels that we are being conditioned to first believe that in order to make it happen. Imagine a half burned down, ransacked store that it's still cleaning up posting a sign to come in we're open for business. It's a strange time in the city. Most people complaining about streets being too dirty and not feeling safe.  It is however a great time for youth and outdoors parties (NYU and Columbia admissions applications up by over 50%), but that group doesn't traditionally turn out to vote. One of the most interesting elections in NY by far.
recent polls. high uncertainty. most of "someone else" is Garcia, who I think is more likely than Yang.

June 17 alternative forecast to compare to outcome: 43
11
8
21
17

This is a forecast just based on the recent polls and what has been the trend at PredictIt. I guess where I can be blindsided most is that ranked choice voting depends a lot on the person who is liked most across a majority of voters, not necessarily who has the most passionate first-past-the-post support. But because there are ranked choice polls on Wikipedia indicating Adams has a firm hold on the lead, my guess is this concern will not be an issue. Another dark horse candidate seems to be Garcia. Will have to watch closely. I feel uncomfortable putting Yang, who had the lead for months, with the lowest chance of the top 3 picks—against Bayes' theorem logic. My honest forecast is . . .
38 - Adams
01 - Stringer
05 - Wiley
28 - Yang
28 - Garcia or someone else

Adams consistently ahead in polls. Wiley and Garcia could make a late run.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_New_York_City_mayoral_election#Opinion_polling

Some combination of https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7002/Who-will-be-elected-New-York-City-mayor-in-2021 and polls from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_New_York_City_mayoral_election

I'm afraid that since ranked choice voting usually favors the guy who has a strong second place support, that Yang is currently that man. I also see similar sentiment around Wiley and Garcia. My forecast weights the polls and prediction markets more now that the scope is within the latter's most effective range.
Betting markets now strongly favouring Adams over Yang 2:1

There seems to be a lot of noise and the runner up is changing week to week, but Adams is consistently tracking upward and the best regarded candidate on the top concern of voters (crime).  "Nearly 44% of voters said they were less likely to vote for Stringer because of the additional accusation of sexual misconduct." is worse than I had thought so Stringer is out again too. It seems Yang, Garcia, and WIley have almost the same shot, albeit a small one at this point. https://pix11.com/news/new-york-elections/pix11-mayors-race-poll-adams-leads-wiley-jumps-to-2nd-after-aoc-endorsement-rival-scandals/
field is crowding, i wonder if Adams will be hurt by this story about his residency, i wonder if Maya Wiley will withstand any scrutiny

AOC's endorsement could mean alot on the ground to turnout voters..With RCV, we have instant runoffs eliminating those with fewest 1st choice, then 2nd choice until there's a majority. I'm thinking Maya Wiley has a decent chance or someone else to rise through the elimination process but I must state that I have not run any numbers on this question because I'm not sure that would help.
Still think Yang has this one in the bag, but adding additional to Wiley + someone else (Garcia)
Garcia ahead in latest Emerson/PIX11 poll, coupled with lower undecided percentage. Holding steady on Adams, waiting for more insight.
Garcia is taking a commanding presence and may run away with enough votes. I'm surprised by this.

https://nypost.com/2021/06/07/eric-adams-leading-new-york-city-mayoral-race-poll-shows/ Interesting to note that 2nd choice amongst voters is still Stringer... and he's 2nd highest in name recognition after Yang. Margin of error is slowly widening in Adams favour but still nothing firm. AOC's endorsement of Wiley changes the playing field a bit but likely not enough to keep her in the running so I'm pulling her back out. (-2 Wiley, +1 Stringer, +1 Adams)
Uncertainty comes from a surprising lack of good polling

i feel like people here are greatly overestimating yang because he is "cool", does podcasts and social media, has new ideas and whatnot. all things that young people who are into politics care are alot about but maybe most voters don't.
Updating a bit for AOC endorsement of Wiley.
Garcia is the "Someone else".  Hard to predict this race.
Reducing Stringer's chances from 2% to 1% based on @smingers  ' comment about the new accusation: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/04/nyregion/scott-stringer-teresa-logan-sexual-misconduct.html
Another accusation against Stringer, just as he was starting, possibly, to find his footing.

Post debate, Garcia seems to have peaked and Yang is stalling. As the race seems to be putting more weight into crime prevention this further bolsters Adams campaign "the segment was more like a joint interview of Adams, who was pressed on a variety of issues" - this tends to show who the other candidates perceive the frontrunner to be "With early voting in the primary less than two weeks away, progressive groups are finally beginning to rally around one candidate: Wiley." https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/02/politics/nyc-mayoral-debate-june-2/index.html

Pretty clear from last night's debate that the people on stage, at least, think Adams and Yang are in the lead. Garcia is showing strength in recent polling on the back of her high profile newspaper endorsements. Though she's the candidate who would appeal to me personally (bias), I found her to have negative charisma on stage, and I struggle to see her attracting much support on the basis of that debate. Stringer has shown more resiliency than I expected after the accusation of sexual impropriety against him. It seems Democratic voters are willing to look the other way when it comes to ambiguous, long-ago claims like the one against him, Biden, etc. Though Adams received some body blows regarding past corruption, he effectively parried on stage and, in my view, was charismatic, likable, and well-versed on the issues, making him a formidable candidate. The more crime rises in salience as an issue (and it seems to be happening), the more I like his chances.
The ranked choice voting means this election is really up for grabs. I will re-evaluate after the debate.

Yang is the non-NYC favorite and will win a lot of votes from people not paying attention. Stringer will win votes with NYC voters who are paying attention and vote as a monolith. Fringe points for fringe candidates.

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/31/nyregion/nyc-mayors-race-june.html Yang's offensive on Garcia likely shows a further weakening of his campaign. It's too early to tell is Garcia can maintain momentum as she is the least funded of the 3 leading candidates and the last to form a PAC. Money still counts and she will likely still lag in spending as we come into the final stretch.  Stringer has spent the most but his campaign in lagging after allegations.  Adams is 3rd in spending so far (Behind Stringer and Yang) and has the largest remaining war chest. I'm glad its turned into a more interesting race but signs are still pointing to Adams pulling it out in the end. https://www.nyccfb.info/VSApps/WebForm_Finance_Summary.aspx?as_election_cycle=2017

I gotta look more into NYC demographics but basically in RCN I don’t think Adams is well set up to pick up support. I suspect that when it all breaks down either Yang’s voters will go to Garcia or Garcia’s voters will go to Yang.

I still think Adams is the real front runner.  Yang falling out of favor.  Kathryn Garcia is booming.  She has kind of come from nowhere, but with an NYT endorsement, I may have "other" too low now.  [1]  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-new-york-mayoral-election-is-no-longer-andrew-yangs-to-lose/
Yang is stumbling, but I believe remains the favor.  Making modest adjustments to account for Yang's stumbles and the rise of Garcia.  I also believe that Garcia will quickly fade.

Kathryn Garcia has the most memorable commercial too. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O7U7_9LepIU.
he has the highest name recognition still so i still consider Yang the favorite, though the race is certainly tightening as expected.

Not sure where to go here after recent polling shows Yang slipping and several other candidates improving. Entrepreneur Andrew Yang is in third, at 16%"
https://emersonpolling.reportablenews.com/pr/garcia-surges-to-lead-in-nyc-mayor-race-while-adams-holds-his-base

New poll seems to have questionable methodology but may indicate a further divide from Yang. It seems Garcia will take a not insignificant number of votes, but its looking more likely we need to heavily consider who the lower ranked candidates' second and third choice votes will go to as they're taken off the ballot. Garcia can likely take a healthy portion of Morales and Wiley's votes with Yang taking the next largest share. Stringers will likely go heavily to Adams. At this point it could be a 3-way split going into the final rounds but at this point it looks like Yang would be the next one out and I'd bet more of his votes will go to Adams. I'm still therefore favouring Adams but this just got more interesting!

An aggregation of recent polling and I believe Andrew Yang will benefit more than the other major candidates with ranked-choice voting. Current polling shows Yang and Adams very tight with Stringer slightly trailing.
giving Adams slightly better odds relative to what the crowd thinks
Looks like Yang and Adams are neck and neck in the latest polls on wikipedia.

Adams is certainly having a surge in the polls, which is probably the result of the shuffling of support from unviable candidates.  However, Adams is pretty conservative for the Democratic Party, especially one that has moved pretty far left in NYC.  Yang's ground game according to a couple of friends of mine in NYC is fair superior to Adams, which I believe, barring some major shake up, will make the difference.  For the moment, I believe that Yang is still the strong favorite.

Three of the last four ranked choice polls have Adams beating Yang. 
Kathryn Garcia is rising and now third place in the polls. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_New_York_City_mayoral_election#Opinion_polling

There are still a lot of undecided voters. I suspect many of them will end up not voting, but enough will that it makes this a tricky forecast. If the election were held today and limited to only voters who have decided right now (i.e. excluding undecided voters), I suspect the odds would be something like Adams at 44%, Yang at 40%, Stringer at 13%, and everyone else combined at around 3% (Garcia is probably the next most likely, but still a long shot). The challenge is in estimating how the undecided voters will break. I'm guessing that the crowd's estimate is on track that Yang has an edge with these undecided voters (especially as a second or third choice), but, given the state of the polls, I'm going to give Adams and Stringer a slight boost in my estimates relative to the crowd. Every ranked choice poll I've seen so far has had either Adams, Yang, or Stringer as the winner after a few rounds of elimination. https://pix11.com/news/new-york-elections/nyc-mayoral-race-adams-surging-poll-finds/
Ranked choice voting makes it more difficult to choose a clear winner.

In contrast to the other responders who are lowering Yang's chances based on recent polling, I'm holding steady. Here's why: "Meanwhile the biggest winner in the poll was “none of the above,” with the number of Democratic voters who are on the fence jumping from 17 percent in March to 23 percent." With RCV, if enough people are on the fence they're going to select the most well-known candidate (that's Yang.) For everyone else who won't make it to 50% of the vote (Wiley, Stringer, write-ins, etc) they may be chosen as the first choice and Yang as the second choice, and Yang wins. "I don't know" is really a vote for Yang.
It's such a toss up right now.

Base rates taken from recent polling. Andrew Yang and Eric Adams lead the polls and have the most recognition and moment, so it is likely one of the two of them will win. Eric Adams has been polling better recently, and also he is favored as a traditional/non-outsider candidate who has support of the mainstream media behind him. Nevertheless, Andrew Yang's has enthusiastic supporters and has been polling favorably, so he also has a good chance of winning, coming in right behind Adams.

Also, more than 20% still undecided and I imagine they are more likely to break for Adams.  Again, I could be entirely wrong.

Polls and name recognition favour Yang, and publicity seems strongly in his favour, but apparently Yankees are pretty concerned about crime and Adams has a strong track record in this space: https://www.economist.com/united-states/2021/05/15/new-yorks-next-mayors-are-accustomed-to-dealing-with-problems-associated-with-growth

A new survey of 1422 likely Democratic primary voters in New York City finds Eric Adams with a slight lead over Andrew Yang in the Mayoral race, both in first-choice votes and a ranked choice simulation. But Kathryn Garcia is surging in the wake of her New York Times endorsement: after receiving just 4% of first-choice votes in interviews conducted prior to the endorsement, she is the first choice of 11% of those interviewed in the two full days following the endorsement. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_New_York_City_mayoral_election#Polling

No change in forecast, but recent polling has Yang leading, with Adams in second, including in a head-to-head with Yang winning 53-47 https://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/nyc-elections-2021/ny-nyc-mayoral-race-poll-latest-20210513-o6g7vjptdfgwzelttmin5t6qla-story.html

Eric Adams fits the local politics that are going on in NYC right now (concerns over rising violent crime rates, Adams was a police officer). The #defundthepolice crowd is in a bubble and most people don't actually want that to happen. So while both Adams and Yang are disliked by "movement" progressives, the DSA/progressive wings of the NYC Democratic Party have taken a massive hit with: 1.) eight years of de Blasio, and 2.) the fact that these policies don't work. So it's a two-way race between to leading candidates disliked by the Very Online corner of the electorate. Adams has more connections to the party, is a top political office in the most populated + most Democratic borough (when factoring in both), and Yang has likely peaked too early, but it's possible for him to pull it off still as well.
Yang still seems very likely to win the primary.

The resent poll has certainly called into question Yang's lead, but it is only one poll and is probably more an indication of support shuffling as some candidates are clearly becoming not viable.  Adams problem is that he is probably too conservative for the progressive Democratic base of NYC.  In flux of African-American support for Adams is not surprising, but he probably has an upper limit that will likely result in him falling short of defeating Yang.  A lot can change in the next six weeks.

Appears this is becoming a two-person race. I continue to think the consensus on GJ Open is overconfident about Yang's chances, he is a narrow favorite with 1/3 of voters remaining undecided. Being a non-traditional pol, Yang may see his supporters not turn out on primary day in what appears, thus far, to be a low-interest election. Best available polling suggests this is about a 55-45 Yang to Adams race when ranked choice is factored. Yang, being the apparent front-runner, will come in for much more scrutiny as primary day nears. This NY Times story on his Startup America org flopping is evidence of that: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/01/nyregion/andrew-yang-venture-for-america-jobs.html Follow this account for more information: https://twitter.com/MayorsRace2021/status/1389203840327692288

Allegations against Stringer will have pretty much ruined his campaign regardless of what happens now. While it's still a crap shoot of how the ranked choice plays out I'm betting it's down to Yang and Adams. Yang has the progressive edge, Adams has the moderates although his recognition is weaker than it should be at this stage to secure a win. The moderates are generally favoured by older voters, who are also more likely to turn out on voting days. But Yang is still undeniably more recognizable at this stage. I'm still betting the moderate will win out at the voting booth Yang's staying power is impressive and I've upped my odds for him.
While Wiley is the only female with a tad of name recogntion in the race, her association with the failed regime of Mayor DeBlasio can and will be used to cancel her out.
Stringer will be done in completely by the allegations against him, many of his major endorsers have withdrawn. Provisionally reapportioning his support mostly to other challengers (i.e, not Yang).

Talking to a number of New York City residence, Yang is going to win, unless he makes a series of unforced errors and one of the other candidates really catches fire and consolidates the non-Yang vote, but they mostly believe that most of the undecides at this point will go to Yang.  Making slight forecast adjustments based on the information.

With two months to go in the Democratic primary a lot can happen, but Yang appears to have solid lead both as the first and second choice of NYC voters.  However, I did downgrade Yang slightly because of the amount of time remaining in the race to account for unforeseen events that might impact the race.  Something to watch is the possible consolidation of progressives behind a single candidate (most likely Stringer or Wiley), which would quickly change the dynamics of the race, especially as a second preference under there ranked system.
Andrew Yang apparently has strong name recognition and appeal given recent polls. Will see how that holds up in the next month.

Moving Yang up on polling, but he has 77% familiarity (22% support) while Adam has only 53% familiarity (and 13% support), with 26% of voters still undecided.  Adams also leads as the most frequent second choice, which will help in ranked-choice voting.  I think it's more likely that Adams closes the gap, but have tightened the race because Yang is the polling front-runner, has optimism, and has lots of resources.

Yang appears to be the clear front runner and has the most awareness around his campaign which counts a lot in a low info density environment like primaries (even for a city as large as NYC). Maya Wiley has emerged as a front runner for the progressive left which is gaining clout in large left-leaning cities.

Yang will win. Along with strong ground game, likeability, a boost from the Presidential primaries, and a highly appealing and unique message (UBI), it's a slam dunk. Especially considering the very strong polling.

Andrew Yang is currently leading the polls, but there are suspicions that Scott or Maya may drop out and endorse the other as a means of combating Yang. Yang is known as a bit of a maverick within the Democratic Party, especially after his presence became so widely known following his participation in the 2020 Democratic National Convention. Consequently, although Yang may win solely off of name recognition alone, it is possible that his enemies might unite against him since he is not considered a party-first establishment candidate.

Two months to go with roughly a quarter of voters undecided leaves a lot of room for movement among the candidates, but it would appear that Yang's early or midpoint lead is pretty strong.  A lot could still change.

I live around 6,000 miles from New York City and like Will Rogers, all I know is what I read in the papers... I was a Manhattan resident during 70s and 80s (I lived in the same West Side building as the shrink who ministered to a famous, cigarette smoking ex-first lady, you know the one...) From a distance and noticing that US politics is about as corrupt as the nations and cities the wonks and ethicists and troll farms call out with their corruption perception indices yatta-yatta, I thinkAndrew Yang brings a fresh face to Gotham Politics. He is gaining momentum thanks to MSM and social media and the inefficacy of the sclerotic Tammany kleptocracy. And he don't got a re-engineered last name like the current mayor.  Digging up dirt on him will result in chorus of anti-Asian accusations.  He might not be as tight with the "real estate lobby" as the Brooklyn boss, but his crew is flexible, can shape-shift.  Antithesis of "machine politics."  New Era Dems endorsement helps a lot.  Who will the likes of Schumer and AOC endorse, and what about "mob influence" (all of them, not just the one that first comes to your mind).  And Cuomo will have to get his beak wet on this too.

re @ccorcoran223's comments https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1258962. Great summary, seems unlikely someone from outside the current pack will be involved at this stage. Base rate for Yang: 70% GJO, 48% Metacalculus, 60% PredictIt = 59% average General:
- Primary date has changed from September to July to match federal elections. Could see negative effect on voter turnout because voters are not used to new date. 
- This will be the first time that NYC will be using ranked choice voting. Could see negative effect on voter turnout because intimated about new system or not knowing enough about the candidates to rank them.
“It was hard to get people to vote in September, it’s going to be harder to get them to vote in June,” she said. “They’re not used to it. And you add in ranked-choice voting, and it’s a lot of confusion. So campaigns are really going to have to do outstanding get-out-the-vote if they really want to win.” [1]
- In 2013 mayoral election, 66% of voters in primary election were 50+ years old [2].
- 3 more debates, one in May, and 2 more in June. 
- Anecdotally I think Yang could see increased turnout among his voters because they tend to be loyal/fanatics. Polling [3]:
- Latest first-past-the-post poll had 50% undecided, which leads me to even the odds due to greater uncertainty. 
- Past two ranked choice polls were financed by Yang's campaign so take them with a grain of salt, but the results were Yang, Adams, Stringer [4]. Digging into the data a little, it looks like 50+ voters were underrepresented based on 2013 voter data, Hispanics were underrepresented based on NYC demographics (although there may be lower Hispanic turnout which would bring the underrepresentation down), and college educated and high income were overrepresented (34% of latest poll had a graduate degree, and median income was $80k compared to $53k of NYC (not voters). Unfortunately the poll did not break down each candidate's favorability by income, so I don't know how to adjust on that factor. Yang had highest favorability of Hispanics among top candidates (49%). And if we look at 55+ voters, Yang and Stringer have the highest favorability (55-60%). Adams has only 42% favorability among 65+ group. Yang has the highest unfavorability among 55+ group (19%). 
- In latest poll, Yang had highest name recognition at 85%, followed by Stringer (64%) and Adams (62%). [5]
- In latest poll, top 3 issues were vaccine distribution and stopping spread of COVID, public education, and jobs. [5]. Although Yang can do well on jobs, I see other candidates being stronger on managing COVID and public education given their experience in elected office.  Finance [6]:
- Rank of candidates by balance is Adams, Stringer, McGuire, Wiley, Yang. Adams and Stringer have over $6 million, while Wiley and Yang have under $2 million. So far everyone but McGuire has spent about $1 million. I expect Adams and Stringer to gain ground on Yang with increased spending.  Summary:
Given the amount of undecideds and Adams/Stringer finances, I'm inclined to even the odds more between Yang, Adams, Stringer, with Wiley following in fourth. Lowering Yang's base rate of 59% down to 40%. Adams/Stringer at 25%. Wiley at 9%.  [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/24/nyregion/nyc-mayor-race-polls.html

First, guess based on a minimal reading of the news.

Andrew Yang is the current front runner. Some specific things in relation to this democratic primary may hurt Mr. Yang, but he still seems most likely to win (source 1). In fact, analysis from 2013 showed that the Democratic primary in New York Mayoral elections is almost always won by the early leader (source 2). The only one who lost after an early lead since 1989 was Anthony Weiner who was marred by scandal. Barring a scandal, Yang seems likely to continue this trend. Given that Yang is also heavily favored in betting markets (-150 or 60% currently) he seems very likely to win the primary (source 3).  1: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-were-watching-in-the-new-york-city-mayoral-race/
2: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/early-leader-in-polls-usually-wins-new-york-mayoral-primary/
3: https://www.oddsshark.com/politics/new-york-city-mayor-odds

McGuire, who was one of Wall Street's highest-ranking Black executives before stepping down to run for mayor, is the only top-tier candidate not participating in the city's public financing program, which means he isn’t subject to spending limits. Money counts. The ranked choice system may help Yang because voters know him from his presidential campaign and will list him second or third if he’s not their first choice. He's the most known but that will become less relevant as time progresses. Ranked choice votes can unexpectedly favour a 3rd choice if the top 2 are split. Yangs celebrity is unlikely to make him top but could favour in the split. Stringer and Wiley are likely to fall as the race progresses but if the top is split 3 ways it could lean to Stringer. Stringer likely respectable 3 or 4. Adams has recognition and support so is likely top 2. Whether he can pull in front is debatable and a win depends on being the 2nd choice of others farther down ballot.
One voting-reform group, FairVote, found that before ranked-choice voting was implemented in parts of the Bay Area in California, plurality-white districts elected a nonwhite representative 35 percent of the time. Under ranked-choice voting, though, those same districts elected a nonwhite representative 60 percent of the time. 62 percent of New York City citizens of voting age are nonwhite. Again, this favours Adams.
Andrew Yang is leading in the polls, trailed by Adams, but no one else seems to have a shot at winning.
what excitement am I missing about Yang? So far he has proven he knows how to bow out of a race, and NYC is a tough sell.

The latest polling shows Yang with a pretty firm lead. But also 20 to 30% undecided. Yang appears to win at the moment in head to head polling and ranked choice voting as well. So for now he seems like the clear favorite, but remains to be seen if that holds as voters get more familiar with the other candidates. Under the ranked choice voting polls (one of which says it's sponsored by the Yang campaign so unclear if it's fully reliable) Yang currently wins about 60-40 over Eric Adams in the final round. So while Yang appears to be the favorite I think it's too early to give him a massive lead in likelihood. It looks like NYC will use ranked choice voting in the 2021 mayor primary which adds an interesting element to it is and is cool to see. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_New_York_City_mayoral_election#Polling
